title: Option to send Ctrl+Alt+Del or Ctrl+Alt_End for nested RDP sessions
author: yderi
body_snippet:
Hello everyone.
I have enabled the "Key combination" option and it works fine to me. But when you open a secondary RDP session to go further (open RDP connection again on remote side) it cannot pass Ctrl+Alt+End combination for the second or third nested session.
It works only for the first one. Some time we have even three or four nested RDP session, it such a kind of security using jump-boxes to go thru.
The trick here is to open on-screen keyboard in the first session and using it, send a ...

iterations.description: Common RDP usability gap: nested sessions need a UI action to send Ctrl+Alt+End (maps to Ctrl+Alt+Del on remote) since the keypress is consumed by the outer session.

comments.author: another-git-hub-user
comments.snippet:
I do not believe this is something that mRemoteNG can do, nor any RDP client. Have you considered using an RD Gateway to connect through instead of using the nested approach? I would expect a mammoth improvement in performance and responsiveness of the RDP sessions with a gateway.

comments.author: TheDevilDan
comments.snippet: Work Around : launch "osk.exe" (virtual keyboard), do CTRL + ALT with the keybord, and "SUPPR" with the virtual keyboard

comments.author: Elddric
comments.snippet: as TheDevilDan says you can use this workaround: launch the virtual keyboard with osk.exe or click start >windows ease of access > Onscreen keyboard. On your physical keyboard do CTRL+ALT . Then on your Virtual keyboard press Delete. This worked for me.

notes:
AI triage (claude): Common RDP usability gap: nested sessions need a UI action to send Ctrl+Alt+End (maps to Ctrl+Alt+Del on remote) since the keypress is consumed by the outer session.
Approach: Add toolbar/context-menu action that calls the MSTSCLib ActiveX SendKeys or focus-then-PostMessage with VK_CANCEL sequence to inject Ctrl+Alt+End into the active RDP session window.
